utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Edith Gross is a survivor. She beat unimaginable odds, endured the horrors of the Holocaust and lived to tell her story.

utterances.speaker: EDITH GROSS
utterances.sentences: In 1944, we heard that the Nazis are coming. And I remember we went to Main Street we were watching when they came in. And they were sotall. And their boots were so shiny. They marched into the city.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Edith was 15 years old living in occupied Czechoslovakia with her older sister and brothers. Her mother had died andfather had left for America when she was two.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: In the first week, we had to wear a yellow star. If you didn`t put it on and you were caught they killed you right away.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: As the Nazi grip on the country tightened Jews were forced into Ghettos and not allowed to run businesses.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: They decided my house, where I lived happened to fall in the ghetto so I didn`t have to move. But they put in, I don`t know, maybe two or threefamilies. It got so crowded, there barely was room to sleep on the floor even.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Then, they were taken to concentration camps.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: They told us pack everything you can you can carry and you have to leave everything behind. On the train the conditions was unbelievable. Alittle pail was in the middle of the cattle car and that was our bathroom. And there were children. There were women. And no privacy of any sort. There was barely room to lie down. And we went for days. It seems like for years. It was a nightmare, terrible. But finally arrived in Birkenau- Auschwitz.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Many did not even survive the journey to the camps.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: When we arrived we did see a smoking crematorium and the smell was terrible. They said leave everything and get off. I remember lining up andwalking from the train into Auschwitz and there sat Mengele with a little stick in his hand first for women and then for men. And he directed the people. This was went to work and this way went to the crematorium. The women were lining up. I ran over to my brother and I gave him a big hug. And I could see his eyes. He was so frightened.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Edith managed to follow her sister to the line. She never saw her brother again. After Auschwitz, Edith and her sister weremoved to a forced labor camp.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: It was very, very hard labor. And there was a quota. And my sister always had back pain so I was very first. I was made sure that I`ve made aquota.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: As the Russians began to close in on their location, the Nazis moved them again, this time to Stutthof concentration camp.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: Five o`clock every morning, they woke us up. We had to line up. Every time person was pushed out. And of course, we knew never to see themagain. Waking us up during the night, and watching somebody being hung. Stutthof was a very, very rough place.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Edith sister became very ill. Her condition deteriorated rapidly.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: I remember she was on the other side of electric wire and I was yelling, Dwartija (my sister`s name). I wanted a last glance because I knewwe were never going to see each other again.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The Nazis becoming desperate amidst Russian advances started forcing the Jews on so called Death Marches.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: We didn`t have any warm clothes of course, and no food, no nothing. And we started to march. People would just bend down, they were shot. Ifyou just did anything, or you spoke, or anything they were shot. We were walking, dead, all over dead all around us. The German, as we walked through the towns, came out to look at the zoo animals. We looked like zoo animals, dirty. And nothing. But nobody throwed us food.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: They marched from Stutthof to Danzig, finally reaching Konigsberg, now known as Kaliningrad in Russia, where they wereliberated by Russian troops.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: Russian tanks arrived but we were very lucky because the Russians were very, very good liberators. Right away they had a hospital. Right awaythere was food, although we couldn`t eat. Our stomachs were so shrunk. And they said to us, "You are liberated."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Edith slowly made her way back to Czechoslovakia.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: When we got to the house where we live in it was taken apart brick by brick.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: With nothing left for her in her hometown, Edith made the journey over many months to try to leave Europe.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: I didn`t want to go to America. I wanted to go to Israel. I wanted to live amongst Jews because I was so, with the antisemitism I said I haveto live with Jews. And that`s when my father was able to get in touch with me through the Red Cross. We waited eight months for the visa. In those days it wasn`t like now. Roosevelt didn`t want the Jews to come here he displaced Jews, even after the war. So I decided I will come to America.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: So she enrolled in school and learned English. Now Edith has seven grandchildren and eight great grandchildren. Today is moreand more Holocaust survivors pass away. Edith makes it her mission to continue to tell her story.

utterances.speaker: RABBI SHIMON STILLERM, CHABAD OF ISLIP TOWNSHIP
utterances.sentences: Since she started speaking she must have reached directly a few 1000 students and communitymembers, residents and probably indirectly a lot more than that. She was someone who experienced the worst evil in the world. She works to bring light to other people in her surroundings. That`s what Judaism is all about.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: She says if she only changes one mind, she`s accomplished something.

utterances.speaker: GROSS
utterances.sentences: Stop hate and take people the way they are. You know, and judge people what they are. Not by religion, not by any color.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Through the Chabad organization in the town of Islip, Long Island, a community center was dedicated in Edith`s honor. Sherecently took a trip to Israel where she visited the Western Wall and Yad Vashem the Holocaust Memorial. Though it has been 80 years since that horrible time, all that she is lost will always remain.
